description: From Middle English availen (“to be of use”), from Old French a (“to”) + vail (from valoir (“to be worth”)).

entries.meaning: Effect in achieving a goal or aim; purpose, use (now usually in negative constructions). [from 15th c.]
examples: I tried fixing it, to no avail
Labor, without economy, is of little avail.

entries.meaning: (now only US) Proceeds; profits from business transactions. [from 15th c.]
examples: the avails of their own industry

entries.meaning: (television, advertising) An advertising slot or package.

examples: While holding an avail yesterday, the candidate lashed out at critics.

entries.meaning: (Britain, acting) Non-binding notice of availability for work.
(oil industry) A readily available stock of oil.
(obsolete) Benefit; value, profit; advantage toward success. [15th–19th c.]

verbs.description: avail (third-person singular simple present avails, present participle availing, simple past and past participle availed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, often reflexive) To turn to the advantage of.
examples: I availed myself of the opportunity.
Artifices will not avail the sinner in the day of judgment.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be of use or advantage; to answer or serve the purpose; to have strength, force, or efficacy sufficient to accomplish the object.
examples: The plea in court must avail.
Medicines will not avail to halt the disease.

entries.meaning: (India, Africa, elsewhere proscribed) To provide; to make available; to use or take advantage of (an opportunity or available resource).
examples: You can avail discounts on food.
